description.narrative: The Afghanistan Sub-national Governance Programme (ASGP) is a multi-donor-assisted project that supports the Government of Afghanistan (GoA) to enhance local governance since 2006. It is implemented by UNDP as international partner and the Independent Directorate for Local Governance (IDLG) and the Independent Administrative Reform and Civil Service Commission (IARCSC) from the GoA. ASGP’s assistance has ensured that sub-national civil servants have basic skills in democratic governance and public administration. The project’s expected outcome is the establishment of an effective, accountable, participatory, and more representative national and sub-national governance structure. This will be achieved by delivering five specific outputs. The outputs are: - Provincial and District Councils are effectively representing their electorates while holding sub-national government administrations accountable; - Provincial and District Governors’ Offices have the capacity to manage provincial and district governance, development and security strategies in accordance with Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS); - Municipalities have the institutional and organizational framework and capacity to collect revenue and deliver basic public services. National systems, procedures and legal frameworks are in place to implement, coordinate and monitor sub–national governance policy; - IDLG and IARCSC have the capacity to coordinate the public reform implementation, and the IARCSC sub-national offices have the capacity to deliver public administration reforms to all sub-national government institutions. ASGP phase II implementation will improve the lives of women by mainstreaming the gender agenda into all aspects of sub-national governance.
